properties.workflow_name: XDR - Email Rule Feature Automation
XDR-Automation for 25456 (Email Rule)
XDR-Email Rule-O/P References (25583)

properties.name: Workflow_Payload
Update Rule - PUT Case Test Status
TestStatus When Trigger Status is OFF (system Level)
Integer_from_Rule_Page
properties.description: Integer_from_Rule_Page

properties.name: Trigger WF from Email RUle TestStatus
String_NotReq_No_Defaut_FromRulePage
properties.description: String_NotReq_No_Defaut_FromRulePage

properties.name: TestStaus When Trigger is Disabled at WF Level
Boolean_from_RulePage
properties.description: Boolean_from_RulePage

1. Create a Email rule (combination of conditions) and Map the Workflow with Input Variables (Post) 
2. Update a Email rule with new condition , add one more workflow (PUT)
3. Create a Workflow havingSend Email task 
4. Verify whthere rule triggered the workflow or not ? 
5. Disable the Rule at system level and Verify workflow is not triggered 
6. Disable the rule at workflow level and verify disabled rule on wf should not trigger and other should trigger 
7. Create a Rule with Invalid WF 
8. Create a Rule with Empty title 
9. Create a Rule with EMpty Conditions 
10. Create a Rule with Empty title in Properties Level
11. Create a rule with display name more than 64 chars
12. Create Rule with invalid schema id - Should throw valid error message
13. Try to delete a rule with invalid id

Creation of workflow 
Creation of Email Rule

properties.name: Header User-Agent (optional)
properties.description: The User-Agent request header is a characteristic string that lets servers and network peers identify the application, operating system, vendor, and/or version of the requesting user agent

properties.name: Headers Cookie (Not Mandatory)
properties.description:
An HTTP cookie (web cookie, browser cookie) is a small piece of data that a server sends to a user's web browser. The browser may store the cookie and send it back to the same server with later requests. Typically, an HTTP cookie is used to tell if two requests come from the same browser—keeping a user logged in, for example. It remembers stateful information for the stateless HTTP protocol.

Cookies are mainly used for three purposes:

Session management
Logins, shopping carts, game scores, or anything else the server should remember

Personalization
User preferences, themes, and other settings

Tracking
Recording and analyzing user behavior

properties.name: Provide Request Body if needed (Ex: Create targets, wf's)
Error Message
properties.description: Created Object Error Message

properties.name: Select Method (EX: GET, PUT, POST, DELETE)
properties.description: The primary or most commonly-used HTTP methods are POST, GET, PUT, PATCH, and DELETE. These methods correspond to create, read, update, and delete (or CRUD) operations, respectively. There are a number of other methods, too, but they are utilized less frequently.

properties.name: Value (Only For Tenant creation) Provide Tenant id
Header Accept (Optional)
properties.description: The Accept request HTTP header indicates which content types, expressed as MIME types, the client is able to understand. The server uses content negotiation to select one of the proposals and informs the client of the choice with the Content-Type response header.

properties.name: Provide Gmail Password to Create A Keys, SMTP and IMAP Targets
properties.description: bsbhsrvqnnwcpzka

properties.name: Provide Email ID to Create A Keys and  Send Email
properties.description: longhornproj2@gmail.com

Scenario: Email Event With Variable Reference

1.	Create Email A keys, Targets and Email Rule
2.	Create Email Accounytkeys
3.	Create SMTP Target
4.	Create IMAP Target
5.	Create Email Event
6.	Create Workflow and Add Email Rule to It.
7.	Adding upper and lower actions with trigger Variables
8.	Update the Event with Description
9.	Extract Event Trigger Status Validation
10.	Create 2nd Workflow and executing to send email
11.	Adding send email, Updating Action and execute workflow to trigger a workflow
12.	Waiting 35 seconds to trigger a worklfow
13.	Extracting Email Trigger workflow WF Instance and validate
14.	Verify the trigger workflow instances, and trigger instances count should be 1
15.	Verify Email trigger WF Execution and Validation
16.	Delete Instance, WF, Event, Trigger, Targets, A Keys
17.	Delete Email Event, (SMTP, IMAP Targets) and Accontkey

properties.body:
{
  "name": "CA SMTP Automation Account-$workflow.definition_workflow_02APYCDD6R67121HPjVKige4bvebdKMSW2O.output.start_time$",
  "title": "CA SMTP Automation Account-$workflow.definition_workflow_02APYCDD6R67121HPjVKige4bvebdKMSW2O.output.start_time$",
  "properties": {
    "no_runtime_user": false,
    "protocol": "SMTP",
    "display_name": "CA SMTP Automation Account-$workflow.definition_workflow_02APYCDD6R67121HPjVKige4bvebdKMSW2O.output.start_time$",
    "default_runtime_user_id": "$activity.definition_activity_02APYCDJFFC8Z5mNMeSlCrSdfzb5tTeTCdu.output.jsonpath_queries.Email Runtime ID$",
    "server": "smtp.gmail.com",
    "port": 587
  },
  "type": "email.smtp_endpoint",
  "base_type": "target"
}

{
  "name": "CA IMAP Automation Account-$workflow.definition_workflow_02APYCDD6R67121HPjVKige4bvebdKMSW2O.output.start_time$",
  "title": "CA IMAP Automation Account-$workflow.definition_workflow_02APYCDD6R67121HPjVKige4bvebdKMSW2O.output.start_time$",
  "properties": {
    "ignore_certificate_errors": true,
    "port": 993,
    "protocol": "IMAP",
    "tls_enabled": true,
    "polling_interval": 30,
    "display_name": "CA IMAP Automation Account-$workflow.definition_workflow_02APYCDD6R67121HPjVKige4bvebdKMSW2O.output.start_time$",
    "default_runtime_user_id": "$activity.definition_activity_02APYCDJFFC8Z5mNMeSlCrSdfzb5tTeTCdu.output.jsonpath_queries.Email Runtime ID$",
    "server": "imap.gmail.com"
  },
  "type": "email.imap_endpoint",
  "base_type": "target"
}
